comment: Horrible experience playing this with my 2 kids. They played well but afterwards commented on how boring the game was. This game will never hit the table again!
Playable at BSW. Dry abstract for my taste. Not worth it for me. Tough thinking through the next series of moves.
Don't get the appeal. The kids at work really love this game. Maybe it's because of all the sparkly marbles.

Children's game. Doesn't get me, due to downtime and randomness.
multi-player solitaire puzzle solving with no time limit. Tedious to the max

I hate puzzle-y games like this. They break my brain, and not in a good way... I end up staring, slack-jawed, and wondering what I should do, whilst not realizing that there is only one thing I *can* do. See Cafe International.

But I do love Bejeweled!

English 2nd edition from 1968. Heavy wear, but complete and intact.
The Central mechanic here is great. The die roll to earn resources is just too dated to be much fun. Keeping it as it seems like a good intro for kids to a market exchange.

Interesting trading game. It's a good well thought out game, but the theme is not strong enough for me. It's too abstract. Totally worth the few bucks I paid at a thrift store, but not something I would ever have bought full price.

Pretty abstract trading game I discovered at the Pax East game library a few years ago. Solid for its time. Nice shiny components and colorful boards but difficult to get to the table with my group.
As a math problem its interesting, but doesn't quite add up to a fun game.

Bazaar with a beer theme

Classic Sid Sackson. Optimze your trading stones trying to get combinations to claim ware cards for points, but the trick is to have as few stones left over as possible. Puzzle type fans will love it, but it works well for families too.

My comprehensive pictorial review of the 2011 edition: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/755432

My comprehensive pictorial review of the 2022 edition: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/3468889

DIY :>

Designer Sid Sackson
Bazaar (1967)
The original version is part of the 3M Bookshelf Series. ???

I can see how this is the precursor to a lot of trading euro games, except this was immediately so funny and the theme came to life. I want to trade with the charts, but they demand certain exchanges, and it's hard to get precise deals. And then the shifting goal cards means certain colors become valuable or worthless instantly. Best of all, on other players' turns you can think about the complicated exchange chart, so there's something to do! And when you realize someone's going for the same card you are, it becomes like Can't Stop to see who's luckier and scores it first.

All I can think of his how this is still better than 99% of modern euros, more depth while also being way easier to learn. Or maybe that's a sign of modern euros being bloated, they're ridiculously complex to get started, while demanding the tiniest amount of brainpower.
